Grand Canyon National Park

One of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World

A Panoramic View of the Grand Canyon

Key Facts

  • Central feature is the Grand Canyon, one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World
  • The park covers 1,217,252 acres; it is bigger than the state of Rhode Island
  • One of the most visited national parks in the United States
  • The Grand Canyon was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979
  • The park celebrated its 100th anniversary on February, 26, 2019
  • The primary public areas of the park are the South and North Rims
  • The park headquarters are at Grand Canyon Village near the South Entrance

Becoming a National Park

  • 1882 - First bill introduced by Senator Benjamin Harrison to establish the Grand Canyon as a National Park; failed
  • 1883 - Second bill introduced by Senator Benjamin Harrison to establish the Grand Canyon as a National Park; failed
  • 1886 - Third bill introduced by Senator Benjamin Harrison to establish the Grand Canyon as a National Park; failed
  • 1893 - President Benjamin Harrison establishes the Grand Canyon as the Grand Canyon Forest Reserve
  • 1906 - President Theodore Roosevelt creates the Grand Canyon Game Reserve
  • 1919 - President Woodrow Wilson signs the Grand Canyon National Park Act
  • 1916 - The National Park Service is established and assumes administration of the Grand Canyon National Park
  • 1975 - The formal Marble Canyon National Monument is made part of the Grand Canyon National Park
  • 2010 - The Grand Canyon National Park is honored with its own coin under the American the Beautiful Quarters program
For more information on the Grand Canyon visit the Grand Canyon National Park website
